title: 105_hr2548
content: The Act titled "Eliminate the Magnet for Illegal Immigration Act of 1997" aims to increase INS investigators to enforce employer sanctions. The "Eliminate the Magnet for Illegal Immigration Act of 1997" authorizes appropriations for hiring, training, and salaries of INS personnel to increase investigators by 365 positions each year for fiscal years 1998 and 1999. These investigators will focus on enforcing employer sanctions in areas with high violations. The "Eliminate the Magnet for Illegal Immigration Act of 1997" authorizes appropriations for hiring INS personnel to enforce employer sanctions in areas with high concentrations of unauthorized aliens who are employed. SEC. 3. Increase in Department of Labor investigators to enforce labor standards. For fiscal years 1998 and 1999, additional funding is authorized for hiring, training, and salaries of Employment Standards Administration personnel at the Department of Labor. This includes increasing the number of investigators by 300 full-time positions each year and providing necessary support for enforcing labor standards. The Department of Labor will assign investigators to prioritize areas with high concentrations of unauthorized aliens for labor standards violations. Increase in investigators in the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices to enforce antidiscrimination provisions. Authorized appropriations for hiring, training, salaries, and expenses of personnel in the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices to increase investigators by 50 full-time positions and provide necessary support for enforcement of immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions. The Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices will increase investigators by 50 full-time positions to investigate and prosecute violations of immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions. Secretary of Labor authority is added to Title II of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Labor is granted subpoena authority to compel witnesses and documents in immigration program investigations and hearings. The Secretary can administer oaths, examine witnesses, and seek court orders for non-compliance with subpoenas. The Secretary of Labor has subpoena authority for immigration program investigations and hearings, including administering oaths and seeking court orders for non-compliance. Additionally, the Act is amended to include a new section on contempt of court. The Secretary of Labor and the Attorney General will establish joint programs to investigate employer sanctions and labor standards, targeting areas with high concentrations of unauthorized aliens. A performance review will be conducted after one year to identify strategies for targeting industries violating both employer sanctions and labor standards. Additionally, there will be employer education initiatives. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant authorities, will conduct a nationwide program to educate employers on their responsibilities regarding employer sanctions, labor standards, and immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions under this Act. Additionally, civil money penalties for hiring, recruiting, and referral violations will be increased. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, with fines ranging from $1,000 to $25,000. These amendments apply to violations occurring after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, penalties for repeated or willful violations of labor standards will be increased. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for violations of labor standards with respect to unauthorized aliens. Penalties for willful or repeated violations will be doubled for a 10-year period following a final determination of violation. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for violations of labor standards with respect to unauthorized aliens. Penalties will be doubled for willful or repeated violations for a 10-year period. Amendments made by this section apply to violations of employer sanctions occurring after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act, excluding violations of labor standards before the Act's enactment. Increasing civil money penalties for unfair immigration-related employment practices. Increasing civil money penalties for unfair immigration-related employment practices. Amendment to section 274B(g)(2)(B) of the Immigration and Nationality Act to raise fines for violations. Effective date applies to violations occurring after 6 months from enactment. The Attorney General will conduct a study on the impact of laws enacted since 1996 that increase employer sanctions on workplace discrimination based on national origin or citizenship. A report with recommendations on preventing such discrimination must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The Act defines key terms such as employer sanctions, immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions, labor standards, and unauthorized alien. The term is defined in section 274A(h)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
